data.title: A quick journey into Tree
data.statement:
The goal is to read a textual representation of a binary tree, construct the tree according to the given instructions, and then concatenate the text values of all the leaves in the tree.

The input consists of lines representing either a {{node}} or a {{leaf}}:
    For {{node}} lines: The {{node}} is connected to its two children, specified by the indices of the lines : 
`node [[index_1]] [[index_2]]`
The first index is the left branch and the second the right. A child can be either a {{node}} or a {{leaf}}.

    For {{leaf}} lines: Create a {{leaf}} with a string label 
`leaf [[label]]`.

   The first line (index {{0}}) always represents the <<root>> of the tree.

    Using this representation of the tree, you need to build the tree and than read it from left to right by concatenating the labels on the leaves.


A simple example to better understand the input format:

`5
node 4 1
leaf abc
leaf ef
leaf 5
node 3 2`

Interpretation of the Example :

`    o
   / \
  o  abc
 / \
5  ef`

testCases.title: Base case
testCases.testIn:
5
node 4 1
leaf abc
leaf ef
leaf 5
node 3 2

testCases.title: Validator 3
testCases.testIn:

node 1 2
leaf But why 
leaf do you ask

data.constraints:
The tree depth is less than <<10>>.
1 ≤ [[N]] ≤ 1024.
The given tree is always a valid tree
data.stubGenerator:
read n:int

loop n 

read node:string(500)

write Concat String
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1>>: An integer [[N]] for the total number of nodes in the tree.
<<Next [[N]] lines>>: A string [[node]] for each {{node}}/{{leaf}} of the tree. The first line (index {{0}}) is the <<root>> of the tree. Each line starts with {{node}} followed by the indices of the child nodes or {{leaf}} followed by the value of the leaf.
data.outputDescription: The text on the {{leaf}} concatenated from the left to the right.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

The goal is to read a textual representation of a binary tree, construct the tree according to the given instructions, and then concatenate the text values of all the leaves in the tree.

The input consists of lines representing either a node or a leaf:
For node lines: The node is connected to its two children, specified by the indices of the lines : 
node index_1 index_2

The first index is the left branch and the second the right. A child can be either a node or a leaf.

For leaf lines: Create a leaf with a string label 
leaf label
.

The first line (index 0) always represents the root of the tree.

Using this representation of the tree, you need to build the tree and than read it from left to right by concatenating the labels on the leaves.


A simple example to better understand the input format:

5
node 4 1
leaf abc
leaf ef
leaf 5
node 3 2


Interpretation of the Example :

    o
   / \
  o  abc
 / \
5  ef
Input
Line 1: An integer N for the total number of nodes in the tree.
Next N lines: A string node for each node/leaf of the tree. The first line (index 0) is the root of the tree. Each line starts with node followed by the indices of the child nodes or leaf followed by the value of the leaf.
Output
The text on the leaf concatenated from the left to the right.
Constraints
The tree depth is less than 10.
1 ≤ N ≤ 1024.
The given tree is always a valid tree
Example
Input
5
node 4 1
leaf abc
leaf ef
leaf 5
node 3 2
Output
5efabc
